Ron,
Fields of Musashi/Sekigahara/memento-mori.  Impermanence of course has Buddhist resonance as well.  Fitting out an entire koshirae in that motif is a bit over the top.  I suppose that there is a chance that it was put together for an early Western buyer, but that example didn't strike me as a typical export item.  

I'm speculating, but that koshirae doesn't seem like mainstream merchant or bushi wear.  It may be more of a gangster or gambler item, or something that someone from another class would wear to pretend while out on the town.  Maybe an equivalent of the mid-late 20th C American biker aesthetic as co-opted by upper-middle-class-baby-boomer Harley owners.    

There are people on this list who have spent a lot more time on late Edo period social history that I have -- any other ideas???

Jim



  Thanks Jim, I'll make note of this info and also pass it on to my friend who owns that "skull" sword. Have you ever heard of "why" this motif was used (other than sybolizing the fields of Musashi)? Would this type of motif be associated with a person of any particular class or status? (This kowakizashi came from a German collection that was gathered in South Africa. The fellow died and his son moved to Missouri for awhile. Interesting origin!)

  Ron
